title: Screen Memory #4
description: Silkscreen print exploring the layered nature of digital memory and physical trace. This piece investigates how our relationship with screens creates both presence and absence in our lived experience.
projectDescription: A series of silkscreen prints examining the psychological and physical traces left by our daily interactions with digital screens. Each print captures a different aspect of how digital interfaces become embedded in our memory and perception.

artistStatement: These prints are about the phantom limb effect of digital interfaces - how the ghost of screens persists in our vision even when we look away. Each layer in the printing process corresponds to a different temporal layer of memory.
processNotes: This particular print required perfect registration across three screens. The transparent middle layer was the most challenging - getting the opacity just right so it suggests the ghostly presence of interface elements.
inspiration: The afterimage effect when looking away from bright screens, and Freud's concept of 'screen memories' - how certain memories mask or stand in for others.
technicalNotes: The blue ink contains a subtle metallic component that only shows up under certain lighting conditions, mimicking the way screens appear different in various environments.
